summary: [0] is our person to focus on. State Counsellor of MyanmarPresident of National League for DemocracyLeader of the OppositionHouse ArrestGeneral ElectionsBooksPopular cultureFamilyAung San Suu Kyi (/aʊŋ ˌsɑːn suː ˈtʃiː/;[citation needed] Burmese: အောင်ဆန်းစုကြည်; MLCTS: aung hcan: cu. krany [ʔàʊɰ̃ sʰáɰ̃ sṵ tɕì]; born 19 June 1945), sometimes abbreviated to Suu Kyi, is a Burmese politician, diplomat, author, and a 1991 Nobel Peace Prize laureate who served as State Counsellor of Myanmar (equivalent to a prime minister) and Minister of Foreign Affairs from 2016 to 2021. [0] has served as the general secretary of National League for DemocracyLeader since National League for DemocracyLeader's founding in 1988, and was registered as National League for DemocracyLeader's chairperson while National League for DemocracyLeader was a legal party from 2011 to 2023. [0] played a vital role in Myanmar's transition from military junta to partial democracy in the 2010s.The youngest daughter of Aung San, Father of Myanmar, and Khin Kyi, [0] was born in Rangoon, British Burma. After graduating from the University of Delhi in 1964 and St Hugh's College, Oxford in 1968, [0] worked at the United Nations for three years. [0] married Michael Aris in 1972, with whom [0] had two children.[0] rose to prominence in the 8888 Uprising of 8 August 1988 and became the General Secretary of National League for DemocracyLeader. In the 1990 elections, National League for DemocracyLeader won 81% of the seats in Parliament, but 81% of the seats in Parliament were nullified, as military junta refused to hand over power, resulting in an international outcry. [0] had been detained before the 1990 elections and remained under house arrest for almost 15 of the 21 years from 1989 to 2010, becoming one of the world's most prominent political prisoners. In 1999, Time magazine named [0] one of the "Children of Gandhi" and Gandhi's spiritual heir to nonviolence. [0] survived an assassination attempt in the 2003 Depayin massacre when at least 70 people associated with National League for DemocracyLeader were killed.National League for DemocracyLeader boycotted the 2010 elections, resulting in a decisive victory for the military-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP). [0] became a Pyithu Hluttaw MP while National League for DemocracyLeader won 43 of the 45 vacant seats in the 2012 by-elections. In the 2015 elections, National League for DemocracyLeader won a landslide victory, taking 86% of the seats in the Assembly of Myanmar—well more than the 67% supermajority needed to ensure that National League for DemocracyLeader's preferred candidates were elected president and second vice president in the presidential electoral college. Although [0] was prohibited from becoming the president due to a clause in the constitution—[0]'s late husband and children are foreign citizens—[0] assumed the newly created role of State Counsellor of Myanmar, a role akin to a prime minister or a head of government.When [0] ascended to the newly created role of State Counsellor of Myanmar, a role akin to a prime minister or a head of government, [0] drew criticism from several countries, organisations and figures over Myanmar's inaction in response to the genocide of the Rohingya people in Rakhine State and refusal to acknowledge that Myanmar's military has committed massacres. Under [0]'s leadership, Myanmar also drew criticism for prosecutions of journalists. In 2019, [0] appeared in the International Court of Justice where [0] defended the Burmese military against allegations of genocide against the Rohingya people.[0], was arrested on 1 February 2021 following a coup d'état that returned the Tatmadaw (Myanmar Armed Forces) to power and sparked protests across Myanmar. Several charges were filed against [0], and on 6 December 2021, [0] was sentenced to four years in prison on two of Several charges. Later, on 10 January 2022, [0] was sentenced to an additional four years on another set of charges. On 12 October 2022, [0] was convicted of two further charges of corruption and [0] was sentenced to two terms of three years' imprisonment to be served concurrent to each other. On 30 December 2022, [0]'s ended with another conviction and an additional sentence of seven years' imprisonment for corruption. [0]'s final sentence was of 33 years in prison, later reduced to 27 years. the United Nations, most European countries, and the United States condemned her trials as politically motivated.

Name: [0] is our person to focus on. [0], like other Burmese names, includes no surname, but is only a personal name, in [0]'s case derived from three relatives: "Aung San" from [0]'s father, "Suu" from [0]'s paternal grandmother, and "Kyi" from [0]'s mother Khin Kyi.In Myanmar, [0] is often referred to as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. Daw, literally meaning "aunt", is not part of [0]'s name but is an honorific for any older and revered woman, akin to "Madam". [0] is sometimes addressed as Daw Suu or Amay Suu ("Mother Suu") by [0]'s supporters.

Personal life: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was born on 19 June 1945 in Rangoon (now Yangon), British Burma. According to Peter Popham, [0] was born in a small village outside Rangoon (now Yangon), British Burma called Hmway Saung. Her father, Aung San, allied with the Japanese during World War II. Her father, Aung San, founded the modern Burmese army and negotiated British Burma's independence from the United Kingdom in 1947; Her father, Aung San, was assassinated by Her father, Aung San,'s rivals in 1947. [0] is a niece of Thakin Than Tun who was the husband of Khin Khin Gyi, the elder sister of her mother Khin Kyi.[0] grew up with her mother Khin Kyi, and two brothers, Aung San Lin and Aung San Oo, in Rangoon (now Yangon), British Burma. Aung San Lin died at the age of eight when Aung San Lin drowned in an ornamental lake on the grounds of the house. [0]'s emigrated to San Diego, California, becoming a United States citizen. After Aung San Lin's , the family moved to a house by Inya Lake where [0] met people of various backgrounds, political views, and religions. [0] was educated in Methodist English High School (now Basic Education High School No. 1 Dagon) for much of [0]'s childhood in British Burma[0] . [0] speaks four languages: Burmese, English, French, and Japanese. [0] is a Theravada Buddhist.her mother Khin Kyi gained prominence as a political figure in the newly formed Burmese government. her mother Khin Kyi was appointed Burmese ambassador to India and Nepal in 1960, and [0] followed her mother Khin Kyi there. [0] studied in the Convent of Jesus and Mary School in New Delhi, and graduated from Lady Shri Ram College, a constituent college of the University of Delhi in New Delhi, with a degree in politics in 1964. [0] continued [0]'s education at St Hugh's College, Oxford, obtaining a B.A. degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics in 1967, graduating with a third-class degree that was promoted per tradition to an MA in 1968. After graduating, [0] lived in New York City with family friend Ma Than E, who was once a popular Burmese pop singer. [0] worked at the United Nations for three years, primarily on budget matters, writing daily to her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris. On 1 January 1972, Aung San Suu Kyi and Aris, a scholar of Tibetan culture and literature, living abroad in Bhutan, were married. The following year, [0] gave birth to Aung San Suu Kyi and Aris, a scholar of Tibetan culture and literature, living abroad in Bhutan,'s first son, Alexander Aris, in London; Aung San Suu Kyi and Aris, a scholar of Tibetan culture and literature, living abroad in Bhutan,'s second son, Kim, was born in 1977. Between 1985 and 1987, [0] was working toward a Master of Philosophy degree in Burmese literature as a research student at the School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS), University of London. [0] was elected as an Honorary Fellow of St Hugh's College, Oxford's in 1990. For two years, [0] was a Fellow at the Indian Institute of Advanced Studies (IIAS) in Shimla, India. [0] also worked for the government of the Union of Burma.In 1988, [0] returned to British Burma to tend for her mother Khin Kyi. her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris's visit in Christmas 1995 was the last time that Aung San Suu Kyi and Aris, a scholar of Tibetan culture and literature, living abroad in Bhutan, met, as [0] remained in British Burma and the Burmese dictatorship denied her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris any further entry visas. her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 1997 which was later found to be terminal. Despite appeals from prominent figures and organizations, including the United States, the United Nations Secretary-General Kofi Annan and Pope John Paul II, the Burmese dictatorship would not grant her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris a visa, saying that the Burmese dictatorship did not have the facilities to care for her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris, and instead urged [0] to leave British Burma to visit her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris. [0] was at that time temporarily free from house arrest but was unwilling to depart, fearing that [0] would be refused re-entry if [0] left, as [0] did not trust the military junta's assurance that [0] could return.her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris died on her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris's 53rd birthday on 27 March 1999. Since 1989, when her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris's was first placed under house arrest, her future husband, Dr. Michael Aris had seen [0] only five times, the last of which was for Christmas in 1995. [0] was also separated from [0]'s children, who live in the United Kingdom, until 2011.On 2 May 2008, after Cyclone Nargis hit British Burma, Aung San Suu Kyi's dilapidated lakeside bungalow lost Aung San Suu Kyi's dilapidated lakeside bungalow's roof and electricity, while Cyclone Nargis also left entire villages in the Irrawaddy delta submerged. Plans to renovate and repair Aung San Suu Kyi's dilapidated lakeside bungalow were announced in August 2009. [0] was released from house arrest on 13 November 2010.

Political career.Political beginning: [0] is our person to focus on. Coincidentally, when [0] returned to Burma in 1988, the long-time military leader of Burma and head of the ruling party, General Ne Win, stepped down. Mass demonstrations for democracy followed that event on 8 August 1988 (8–8–88, a day seen as auspicious), which were violently suppressed in what came to be known as the 8888 Uprising. On 24 August 1988, [0] made [0]'s first public appearance at the Yangon General Hospital, addressing protestors from a podium. On 26 August, [0] addressed half a million people at a mass rally in front of the Shwedagon Pagoda in the capital, calling for a democratic government. However, in September 1988, a new military junta took power.Influenced by both Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of non-violence and also by the Buddhist concepts, [0] entered politics to work for democratization, helped found the National League for Democracy on 27 September 1988, but was put under house arrest on 20 July 1989. [0] was offered freedom if [0] left Burma, but [0] refused. Despite [0]'s philosophy of non-violence, a group of ex-military commanders and senior politicians who joined the National League for Democracy during the crisis believed that [0] was too confrontational and left the National League for Democracy. However, [0] retained enormous popularity and support among the National League for Democracy youths with whom [0] spent most of [0]'s time.During the crisis, the previous democratically elected Prime Minister of Burma, U Nu, initiated to form an interim government and invited opposition leaders to join the previous democratically elected Prime Minister of Burma, U Nu,. Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had signaled Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's readiness to recognize an interim government. However, [0] categorically rejected the previous democratically elected Prime Minister of Burma, U Nu,'s by saying "the future of the opposition would be decided by masses of the people". Ex-Brigadier General Aung Gyi, another influential politician at the time of the 8888 crisis and the first chairman in the history of the NLD, followed the suit and rejected U Nu's plan after [0]'s refusal. Ex-Brigadier General Aung Gyi, another influential politician at the time of the 8888 crisis and the first chairman in the history of the NLD, later accused several the National League for Democracy members of being communists and resigned from the National League for Democracy.
Political career.1990 general election and Nobel Peace Pr: Aung San Suu Kyi is our person to focus on. In 1990, the military junta called a general election, in which [0] received 59% of the votes, guaranteeing [0] 80% of the parliament seats. Some[who?] claim that Aung San Suu Kyi would have assumed the office of Prime Minister. Instead, the results were nullified and the military refused to hand over power, resulting in an international outcry. Aung San Suu Kyi was placed under house arrest at Aung San Suu Kyi's home on University Avenue ( WikiMiniAtlas16°49′32″N 96°9′1″E﻿ / ﻿16.82556°N 96.15028°E﻿ / 16.82556; 96.15028) in Rangoon, during which time Aung San Suu Kyi was awarded the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought in 1990, and the Nobel Peace Prize one year later. Aung San Suu Kyi's sons Alexander and Kim accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on Aung San Suu Kyi's behalf. Aung San Suu Kyi used the Nobel Peace Prize's US$1.3 million prize money to establish a health and education trust for the Burmese people. Around this time, Aung San Suu Kyi chose nonviolence as an expedient political tactic, stating in 2007, "Aung San Suu Kyi do not hold to nonviolence for moral reasons, but for political and practical reasons."The decision of the Nobel Committee mentions:the Nobel Committee has decided to award the Nobel Peace Prize to Aung San Suu Kyi for her non-violent struggle for democracy and human rights.... her non-violent struggle for democracy and human rights is one of the most extraordinary examples of civil courage in Asia in recent decades. Aung San Suu Kyi has become an important symbol in the struggle against oppression ...... In awarding the Nobel Peace Prize to Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Committee wishes to honour Aung San Suu Kyi for Aung San Suu Kyi's unflagging efforts and to show the Nobel Committee's support for the many people throughout the world who are striving to attain democracy, human rights, and ethnic conciliation by peaceful means. In 1995 Aung San Suu Kyi delivered the keynote address at the Fourth World Conference on Women in Beijing.
Political career.1996 attack: [0] is our person to focus on. On 9 November 1996, the motorcade that Aung San Suu Kyi was traveling in with other National League for Democracy leaders Tin Oo and Kyi Maung, was attacked in Yangon. About 200 men swooped down on the motorcade that Aung San Suu Kyi was traveling in with other National League for Democracy leaders Tin Oo and Kyi Maung, wielding metal chains, metal batons, stones and other weapons. The car that Aung San Suu Kyi was in had The car that Aung San Suu Kyi was in's rear window smashed, and the car with Tin Oo and Kyi Maung other National League for Democracy leaders Tin Oo and Kyi Maung had the car with Tin Oo and Kyi Maung's rear window and two backdoor windows shattered. It is believed About 200 men were members of the Union Solidarity and Development Association (USDA) who were allegedly paid Ks.500/- (@ USD $0.50) each to participate.[citation needed] the Union Solidarity and Development Association (USDA) lodged an official complaint with the police, and according to reports the government launched an investigation, but no action was taken. (Amnesty International 120297)[unreliable source?]
Political career.House arrest: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] was placed under house arrest for a total of 15 years over a 21-year period, on numerous occasions, since [0] began [0]'s political career, during which time [0] was prevented from meeting [0]'s party supporters and international visitors. In an interview, [0] said that while under house arrest [0] spent [0]'s time reading philosophy, politics and biographies that [0]'s husband had sent [0]. [0] also passed the time playing the piano and was occasionally allowed visits from foreign diplomats as well as from [0]'s personal physician.Although under house arrest, [0] was granted permission to leave Burma under the condition that [0] never return, which [0] refused: "As a mother, the greater sacrifice was giving up [0]'s sons, but [0] was always aware of the fact that others had given up more than [0]. [0] never forget that my colleagues who are in prison suffer not only physically, but mentally for my colleagues who are in prison's families who have no security outside – in the larger prison of Burma under authoritarian rule."The media were also prevented from visiting [0], as occurred in 1998 when journalist Maurizio Giuliano, after photographing [0], was stopped by customs officials who then confiscated all journalist Maurizio Giuliano's films, tapes and some notes. In contrast, [0] did have visits from government representatives, such as during her autumn 1994 house arrest when [0] met the leader of Burma, General Than Shwe and General Khin Nyunt on 20 September in the first meeting since [0] had been placed in detention. On several occasions during her autumn 1994 house arrest, [0] had periods of poor health and as a result was hospitalized.Burma detained and kept [0] imprisoned because Burma viewed [0] as someone "likely to undermine the community peace and stability" of Burma, and used both Article 10(a) and 10(b) of the 1975 State Protection Act (granting Burma the power to imprison people for up to five years without a trial), and Section 22 of the "Law to Safeguard the State Against the Dangers of Those Desiring to Cause Subversive Acts" as legal tools against [0]. [0] continuously appealed [0]'s detention, and many nations and figures continued to call for [0]'s release and that of 2,100 other political prisoners in Burma. On 12 November 2010, days after the junta-backed Union Solidarity and Development Party (USDP) won elections conducted after a gap of 20 years, the junta finally agreed to sign orders allowing [0]'s release, and [0]'s house arrest term came to an end on 13 November 2010.
Political career.United Nations involvement: [0] is our person to focus on. The United Nations (UN) has attempted to facilitate dialogue between the junta and Aung San Suu Kyi. On 6 May 2002, following secret confidence-building negotiations led by The United Nations (UN), the junta released [0]; a government spokesman said that [0] was free to move "because the junta and Aung San Suu Kyi are confident that the junta and Aung San Suu Kyi can trust each other". [0] proclaimed "a new dawn for the junta". However, on 30 May 2003 in an incident similar to the 1996 attack on [0], a government-sponsored mob attacked [0]'s caravan in the northern village of Depayin, murdering and wounding many of [0]'s supporters. [0] fled the scene with the help of [0]'s driver, Kyaw Soe Lin, but was arrested upon reaching Ye-U. the junta imprisoned [0] at Insein Prison in Rangoon. After [0] underwent a hysterectomy in September 2003, the junta again placed [0] under house arrest in Rangoon.The results from the The United Nations (UN) facilitation have been mixed; Razali Ismail, UN special envoy to Burma, met with [0]. Razali Ismail, UN special envoy to Burma, resigned from Razali Ismail, UN special envoy to Burma,'s post the following year, partly because Razali Ismail, UN special envoy to Burma, was denied re-entry to Burma on several occasions. Several years later in 2006, Ibrahim Gambari, UN Undersecretary-General (USG) of Department of Political Affairs, met with [0], met. Ibrahim Gambari, UN Undersecretary-General (USG) of Department of Political Affairs also met with [0] later the same year. On 2 October 2007 Ibrahim Gambari, UN Undersecretary-General (USG) of Department of Political Affairs returned to talk to [0] again after seeing Than Shwe and other members of the senior leadership in Naypyidaw. State television broadcast [0] with Ibrahim Gambari, UN Undersecretary-General (USG) of Department of Political Affairs, stating that they had met twice. broadcast was [0]'s first appearance in state media in the four years since [0]'s current detention began.The The United Nations (UN) Working Group for Arbitrary Detention published an Opinion that Aung San Suu Kyi's deprivation of liberty was arbitrary and in contravention of Article 9 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948, and requested that the authorities in Burma set [0] free, but the authorities in Burma ignored requested at that time. an Opinion that Aung San Suu Kyi's deprivation of liberty was arbitrary and in contravention of Article 9 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights 1948 said that according to the junta's reply, "[0] has not been arrested, but has only been taken into protective custody, for [0]'s own safety", and while "the junta could have instituted legal action against [0] under Burma's domestic legislation ... the junta has preferred to adopt a magnanimous attitude, and is providing [0] with protection in [0]'s own interests".Such claims were rejected by Brig-General Khin Yi, Chief of Myanmar Police Force (MPF). On 18 January 2007, the state-run paper New Light of Myanmar accused [0] of tax evasion for spending [0]'s Nobel Prize money outside Burma. accused followed the defeat of a US-sponsored United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Burma as a threat to international security; a US-sponsored United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Burma as a threat to international security was defeated because of strong opposition from China, which has strong ties with the military junta (China, which has strong ties with the military junta later voted against a US-sponsored United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Burma as a threat to international security, along with Russia and South Africa).In November 2007, it was reported that [0] would meet her political allies National League for Democracy along with a government minister. the junta made reported on state TV and radio just hours after The United Nations (UN) ended UN special envoy Ibrahim Gambari's second visit to Burma. her political allies National League for Democracy confirmed that her political allies National League for Democracy had received the invitation to hold talks with [0]. However, the process delivered few concrete results.On 3 July 2009, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon went to Burma to pressure the junta into releasing [0] and to institute democratic reform. However, on departing from Burma, UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon was "disappointed" with the visit after junta leader Than Shwe refused permission for UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to visit [0], citing [0]'s ongoing trial. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon was "deeply disappointed that the junta have missed a very important opportunity".
Political career.2007 anti-government protests: Aung San Suu Kyi is our person to focus on. Protests led by Buddhist monks began on 19 August [0] following steep fuel price increases, and continued each day, despite the threat of a crackdown by the military.On 22 September [0], although still under house arrest, Aung San Suu Kyi made a brief public appearance at the gate of Aung San Suu Kyi's residence in Yangon to accept the blessings of Buddhist monks who were marching in support of human rights. It was reported that Aung San Suu Kyi had been moved the following day to Insein Prison (where Aung San Suu Kyi had been detained in 2003), but meetings with UN envoy Ibrahim Gambari near Aung San Suu Kyi's Rangoon home on 30 September and 2 October established that Aung San Suu Kyi remained under house arrest.
Political career.2009 trespass incident: [0] is our person to focus on. On 3 May 2009, an American man, identified as John Yettaw, swam across Inya Lake to [0]'s uninvited and was arrested when an American man, identified as John Yettaw made an American man, identified as John Yettaw's return trip three days later. an American man, identified as John Yettaw had attempted to make a similar trip two years earlier, but for unknown reasons was turned away. an American man, identified as John Yettaw later claimed at trial that an American man, identified as John Yettaw was motivated by a divine vision requiring an American man, identified as John Yettaw to notify [0] of an impending terrorist assassination attempt. On 13 May, [0] was arrested for violating the terms of [0]'s house arrest because an American man, identified as John Yettaw, was allowed to stay in [0]'s for two days before an American man, identified as John Yettaw attempted the swim back. [0] was later taken to Insein Prison, where [0] could have faced up to five years' confinement for the intrusion. trial [0] [0]'s began on 18 May and a small number of protesters gathered outside. Diplomats and journalists were barred from attending trial; however, on one occasion, several diplomats from Russia, Thailand and Singapore and journalists were allowed to meet [0]. The prosecution had originally planned to call 22 witnesses. The prosecution also accused an American man, identified as John Yettaw of embarrassing the country. During the ongoing defence case, [0] said [0] was innocent. The defence was allowed to call only one witness (out of four), while The prosecution was permitted to call 14 witnesses. The court rejected two character witnesses, NLD members Tin Oo and Win Tin, and permitted The defence to call only a legal expert. According to one unconfirmed report, the junta was planning to, once again, place [0] in detention, this time in a military base outside the city. In a separate trial, an American man, identified as John Yettaw said an American man, identified as John Yettaw swam to [0]'s to warn [0] that [0]'s life was "in danger". The national police chief later confirmed that an American man, identified as John Yettaw was the "main culprit" in the case filed against [0]. According to aides, [0] spent [0]'s 64th birthday in jail sharing biryani rice and chocolate cake with [0]'s guards.[0]'s arrest and subsequent trial received worldwide condemnation by the UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations Security Council, Western governments, South Africa, Japan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, of which Burma is a member. Burma strongly condemned the statement, as the statement created an "unsound tradition" and criticised Thailand for meddling in Burma's internal affairs. The Burmese Foreign Minister Nyan Win was quoted in the state-run newspaper New Light of Myanmar as saying that the incident "was trumped up to intensify international pressure on Burma by internal and external anti-government elements who do not wish to see the positive changes in those countries' policies toward Burma". Ban responded to an international campaign by flying to Burma to negotiate, but Than Shwe rejected all of Ban's requests.On 11 August 2009, trial concluded with [0] being sentenced to imprisonment for three years with hard labour. imprisonment for three years with hard labour was commuted by the military rulers to further house arrest of 18 months. On 14 August, US Senator Jim Webb visited Burma, visiting with Than Shwe and later with [0]. During visiting, US Senator Jim Webb negotiated an American man, identified as John Yettaw's release and deportation from Burma. Following sentenced, lawyers of Aung San Suu Kyi said lawyers of Aung San Suu Kyi would appeal against further house arrest of 18 months. On 18 August, United States President Barack Obama asked the country's military leadership to set free all political prisoners, including [0]. In [0]'s , [0] had argued that sentenced was unwarranted. However, [0]'s further house arrest of 18 months was rejected by a Burmese court on 2 October 2009. Although a Burmese court accepted the argument that the 1974 constitution, under which [0] had been charged, was null and void, a Burmese court also said the provisions of the 1975 security law, under which [0] has been kept under house arrest, remained in force. rejected effectively meant that [0] would be unable to participate in the elections scheduled to take place in 2010—the first in Burma in two decades. [0]'s lawyer stated that [0]'s legal team would pursue a new appeal within 60 days.
Political career.Late 2000s: International support for re: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] has received vocal support from Western nations in Europe, Australia and North and South America, as well as India, Israel, Japan the Philippines and South Korea. In December 2007, the US House of Representatives voted unanimously 400–0 to award Aung San Suu Kyi the Congressional Gold Medal; the Senate concurred on 25 April 2008. On 6 May 2008, President George W. Bush signed legislation awarding Aung San Suu Kyi the Congressional Gold Medal. [0] is the first recipient in American history to receive the Congressional Gold Medal while imprisoned. More recently, there has been growing criticism of [0]'s by Burma's's neighbours in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, particularly from Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines and Singapore. At one point Malaysia warned Burma's that Burma's faced expulsion from ASEAN as a result of her detention[0]. Other nations including South Africa, Bangladesh and the Maldives also called for [0]'s release. The United Nations has urged Burma's to move towards inclusive national reconciliation, the restoration of democracy, and full respect for human rights. In December 2008, the The United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution condemning the human rights situation in Burma and calling for Aung San Suu Kyi's release—80 countries voting for the resolution, 25 against and 45 abstentionsa resolution condemning the human rights situation in Burma and calling for Aung San Suu Kyi's release—80 countries voting for the resolution, 25 against and 45 abstentions. Other nations, such as China and Russia, are less critical of the regime and prefer to cooperate only on economic matters. Indonesia has urged China to push Burma's for reforms. However, Samak Sundaravej, former Prime Minister of Thailand, criticised the amount of support for [0], saying that "Europe uses [0] as a tool. If it's not related to [0], you can have deeper discussions with Myanmar."Vietnam, however, did not support calls by other ASEAN member states for Myanmar to free [0], state media reported Friday, 14 August 2009. The state-run Việt Nam News said "Vietnam had no criticism of Myanmar's decision 11 August 2009 to place [0] under house arrest for the next 18 months, effectively barring [0] from elections scheduled for 2010. "It is "Vietnam's view that the [0] trial is an internal affair of Myanmar", Vietnamese government spokesman Le Dung stated on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. In contrast with other ASEAN member states, Vietnamese government spokesman Le Dung said "Vietnam has always supported Myanmar and hopes Myanmar will continue to implement the "roadmap to democracy" outlined by "Vietnam's .Nobel Peace Prize winners (Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the Dalai Lama, Shirin Ebadi, Adolfo Pérez Esquivel, Mairead Corrigan, Rigoberta Menchú, Prof. Elie Wiesel, US President Barack Obama, Betty Williams, Jody Williams and former US President Jimmy Carter) called for the rulers of Burma's to release [0] to "create the necessary conditions for a genuine dialogue with [0] and all concerned parties and ethnic groups to achieve an inclusive national reconciliation with the direct support of The United Nations". Some of the money [0] received as part of Nobel Peace Prize helped fund higher education grants to Burmese students through the London-based charity Prospect Burma.It was announced prior to elections scheduled for 2010 that [0] may be released "so [0] can organize [0]'s ", However, [0] was not allowed to run. On 1 October 2010 Burma's announced that [0] would be released on 13 November US President Barack Obama personally advocated released, during the US-ASEAN Summit of 2009.The US Government hoped that successful general elections would be an optimistic indicator of Burma's's sincerity towards eventual democracy. The Hatoyama government which spent 2.82 billion yen in 2008, has promised more Japanese foreign aid to encourage Burma's to release [0] in time for elections scheduled for 2010; and to continue moving towards democracy and the rule of law.In a personal letter to [0], UK Prime Minister Gordon Brown cautioned Burma's of the potential consequences of rigging elections as "condemning Burma's to more years of diplomatic isolation and economic stagnation".[0] met with many heads of state and opened a dialog with the Minister of Labor Aung Kyi (not to be confused with [0]). [0] was allowed to meet with senior members of [0]'s at the State House, however meet took place under close supervision.
Political career.2010 release: [0] is our person to focus on. Political beliefs: Aung San Suu Kyi is our person to focus on. It is not power that corrupts, but fear. Fear of losing [0] corrupts those who wield [0] and fear of the scourge of power corrupts those who are subject to it.—Freedom from FearAsked what democratic models Myanmar could look to, Myanmar said: "We have many, many lessons to learn from various places, not just the Asian countries like South Korea, Taiwan, Mongolia, and Indonesia." Myanmar also cited "eastern Europe and countries, which made the transition from communist autocracy to democracy in the 1980s and 1990s, and the Latin American countries, which made the transition from military governments. And we cannot of course forget South Africa, because although South Africa wasn't a military regime, South Africa was certainly an authoritarian regime." Myanmar added: "We wish to learn from everybody who has achieved a transition to democracy, and also ... our's great strong point is that, because our are so far behind everybody else, our can also learn which mistakes we should avoid."In a nod to the deep US political divide between Republicans led by Mitt Romney and the Democrats by Obama—then battling to win the 2012 presidential election—Myanmar stressed, "Those of you who are familiar with American politics Myanmar'm sure understand the need for negotiated compromise."

Health problems: [0] is our person to focus on. [0] underwent surgery for a gynecological condition in September 2003 at Asia Royal Hospital during [0]'s house arrest. [0] also underwent minor foot surgery in December 2013 and eye surgery in April 2016. In June 2012, [0]'s doctor Tin Myo Win said that [0] had no serious health problems, but weighed only 48 kilograms (106 lb), had low blood pressure, and could become weak easily.After being arrested and detained on 1 February 2021, there were concerns that Aung San Suu Kyi's health is deteriorating. However, according to military's spokesperson Zaw Min Tun, special attention is given to Aung San Suu Kyi's health and living condition. Don Pramudwinai also said that "[0] was in good health, both physically and mentally".Although a junta spokesperson claimed that [0] is in good health, since being sent back to prison in September 2023, it is reported that Aung San Suu Kyi's health is worsening and "suffering a series of toothache and unable to eat". [0]'s request to see a dentist had been denied. [0]'s son is urging junta to allow [0] to receive medical assistance.
